A **barrow wight**, W, is a [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. Barrow wights are [wraith-like](/wiki/Wraith_\(monster_class\) "Wraith (monster class)") [undead](/wiki/Undead "Undead") that will seek out items such as weapons and armor to pick up, and will [follow](/wiki/Follow "Follow") [you](/wiki/You "You") to other levels if they are adjacent to you.

A barrow wight has a weapon attack with the ability to [drain life](/wiki/Drain_life "Drain life"), the ability to cast one mage [monster spell](/wiki/Monster_spell "Monster spell") during each of its turns, and a claw attack. They possess [poison resistance](/wiki/Poison_resistance "Poison resistance"), [sleep resistance](/wiki/Sleep_resistance "Sleep resistance") and [cold resistance](/wiki/Cold_resistance "Cold resistance").

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [3 History](#History)

- [4 Origin](#Origin)

- [5 Variants](#Variants)

  - [5.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [5.2 UnNetHack](#UnNetHack)
  - [5.3 dNetHack](#dNetHack)

- [6 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

- [7 References](#References)

## Generation

Randomly-generated barrow wights are always created [hostile](/wiki/Hostile "Hostile").

Barrow wights appear among the random W that are part of the second [quest](/wiki/Quest "Quest") [monster class](/wiki/Monster_class "Monster class") for [Wizards](/wiki/Wizard "Wizard") and make up 6⁄175 of the monsters randomly generated on the [Wizard quest](/wiki/Wizard_quest "Wizard quest").

Barrow wights are [always generated with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") a [long sword](/wiki/Long_sword "Long sword") and a [knife](/wiki/Knife "Knife").[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

A barrow wight [does not leave a corpse](/wiki/Corpseless "Corpseless") upon death.

Characters that die at the hands of a barrow wight and leave a [bones](/wiki/Bones "Bones") file will arise as a named [wraith](/wiki/Wraith "Wraith") instead of a [ghost](/wiki/Ghost "Ghost").

## Strategy

Barrow wights move at the same [speed](/wiki/Speed "Speed") as an unhasted, unburdened hero, and can be more troublesome than expected: their monster spells typically include [stun](/wiki/Stun_\(monster_spell\) "Stun (monster spell)"), [haste self](/wiki/Haste_self_\(monster_spell\) "Haste self (monster spell)"), [cure self](/wiki/Cure_self "Cure self"), and [psi bolt](/wiki/Psi_bolt "Psi bolt"). They will often throw their knife (and any other projectiles they comes across) upon spotting you. Though their [melee](/wiki/Melee "Melee") attacks are not particularly strong, they can drain levels and still cause significant damage using their long sword; their spellcasting can also potentially prolong a fight, and may be even more trouble when fighting multiple foes. Alert players, especially ones that can stay out of melee range, can handle them fairly quickly and without too much trouble.

Once a barrow wight is destroyed, the long sword may be of interest to [lawful](/wiki/Lawful "Lawful") characters looking to dip for [Excalibur](/wiki/Excalibur "Excalibur"). Barrow wights are also a source of knives for characters that seek to utilize them as projectiles, e.g. [Healers](/wiki/Healer "Healer") and [Rogues](/wiki/Rogue "Rogue").

## History

The barrow wight first appears in [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0").

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Wight](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wight "wikipedia:Wight")***

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Barrow-wight](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barrow-wight "wikipedia:Barrow-wight")***

A "barrow" is a burial mound, such as the ones used in Neolithic times, while the word "wight" generally refers to a form of undead; the latter word describes a living human being in its original Old English usage, and has since come to be used within fantasy works such as *A Song of Ice and Fire* and *Vampire: The Masquerade* to describe immortal ghost-like beings. The earliest example of the modern wight is in [William Morris's](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Morris "wikipedia:William Morris") 1869 translation of the *[Grettis saga](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grettis_saga "wikipedia:Grettis saga")*, a work of Icelandic family prose; here, *haugbui* (referring to undead monsters Glámr and Kárr) is translated as "barrow-wight".

*NetHack* derives barrow wights from [J. R. R. Tolkien](/wiki/J._R._R._Tolkien "J. R. R. Tolkien")'s world of Middle-earth, which in turn bases them on Nordic folklores such as the ones translated by Morris, and they are typically depicted as wraith-like evil spirits; in *The Lord of the Rings*, the [hobbit](/wiki/Hobbit "Hobbit") Frodo and his company narrowly escape a barrow-wight with the aid of Tom Bombadil, who then arms the group using "barrow-blades" and ancient swords from the wight's treasure-hoard (the basis for the barrow wight's *NetHack* starting inventory).

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), barrow wights are a decent monster form for early [Dopplegangers](/wiki/Doppelganger_\(starting_race\) "Doppelganger (starting race)") due to their resistances and level-draining attack, though their carry cap is somewhat low. This also applies to [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM") and [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM").

### UnNetHack

In [UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack"), barrow wights are slightly more common.

If a hero is killed by a [Nazgul](/wiki/Nazgul "Nazgul"), they will rise as a barrow wight instead of a ghost if a bones file is created.

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack"), and [notnotdNetHack](/wiki/NotnotdNetHack "NotnotdNetHack"), a barrow wight's long sword has a 1⁄5 chance of being made of [silver](/wiki/Silver "Silver") and a 1⁄5 chance of being made of [gold](/wiki/Gold_\(material\) "Gold (material)") - it also has an independent 1⁄20 chance of generating with the "lesser holy" [object property](/wiki/Object_property "Object property").

Barrow wights are a tempting source of long swords for lawful characters to dip and turn into Excalibur, since creating Excalibur this way retains any object properties and [object materials](/wiki/Object_materials_\(dNetHack\) "Object materials (dNetHack)"): silver weapons naturally deal +1d20 silver damage, while gold weapons raise a blessed weapon's holy bonus damage to +1d20 and raise a cursed weapon's unholy bonus damage to +4d9; the lesser holy property adds +1d8 holy damage for blessed weapons with the property that is separate from the normal +1d4 damage bonus.

## Encyclopedia entry

When he came to himself again, for a moment he could recall  
nothing except a sense of dread. Then suddenly he knew that  
he was imprisoned, caught hopelessly; he was in a barrow. A  
Barrow-wight had taken him, and he was probably already under  
the dreadful spells of the Barrow-wights about which whispered  
tales spoke. He dared not move, but lay as he found himself:  
flat on his back upon a cold stone with his hands on his  
breast.

\[ The Fellowship of the Ring, by J.R.R. Tolkien ]

A barrow wight has a weapon attack with the ability to drain life, the ability to cast one mage monster spell during each of its turns, and a claw attack. They possess poison resistance, sleep resistance and cold resistance.

Barrow wights appear among the random W that are part of the second quest monster class for Wizards and make up 6⁄175 of the monsters randomly generated on the Wizard quest.

Characters that die at the hands of a barrow wight and leave a bones file will arise as a named wraith instead of a ghost.

Barrow wights move at the same speed as an unhasted, unburdened hero, and can be more troublesome than expected: their monster spells typically include stun, haste self, cure self, and psi bolt. They will often throw their knife (and any other projectiles they comes across) upon spotting you. Though their melee attacks are not particularly strong, they can drain levels and still cause significant damage using their long sword; their spellcasting can also potentially prolong a fight, and may be even more trouble when fighting multiple foes. Alert players, especially ones that can stay out of melee range, can handle them fairly quickly and without too much trouble.

Once a barrow wight is destroyed, the long sword may be of interest to lawful characters looking to dip for Excalibur. Barrow wights are also a source of knives for characters that seek to utilize them as projectiles, e.g. Healers and Rogues.
